is Shane Hasty for the InfoQ Engineering Culture Podcast Today I'm sitting down with Erin Doyle Erin welcome Thanks for
taking the time to talk to us Thank you Really excited to be here My normal
starting point on these conversations is is Aaron I would describe myself as a a
generalist a jack of all trades I've done a lot over the course of my career
Started out at the Kennedy Space Center doing full stack development for the the workers who would work on the space
shuttle Um after that I did sort of product support uh customer support solutions engineering which I wouldn't
say was my favorite job but I learned a lot about troubleshooting debugging
jumping into code that I didn't write and that was pretty valuable After that I uh did mobile
development which I was brand new to and it was new to the company So that was an
exciting journey And then I moved on to a full stack uh
e-commerce team and that's when I really dove deep into web accessibility because
that was a huge priority for the product and uh had to learn all about that And
so then I I kind of got into talking and teaching workshops on web accessibility and then after that I did
a little consultancy um which was another completely different experience had to do
everything all the front all the back all the DevOps And then eventually I moved over to a platform team So I'd
done full stack development forever And then I got into platform development because I I love the idea of supporting
developers as my customers Um I love doing the work to help enable you know
my teammates fellow developers to uh work more efficiently effectively Um and so I got to do a lot
more of that over on the platform team Uh got to wear a lot of hats S sur devx
devpro ops everything So now my final step in my journey I just started a new
job as a founding engineer at Quotient where we do develop development productivity software So that's been
kind of a a dream of mine and of course as a founding engineer I get to wear all the hats So it's kind of the the buildup
of my career has led to this and I'm really excited about it Thank you So
let's dig in first in the one of those early
passions accessibility web accessibility
Uh why does it matter so much Yeah it's huge and and primarily it was huge to
our customers at that company because um we had a a white label application for
businesses and uh these are businesses selling a product and so uh a um there
was a lot of um legal ramifications of websites that are trying to sell product
if they're not accessible people could sue for that and and we did have customers who had been sued for their
own websites in the past So it was a huge priority for them to be safe from legal action But of but also if a
customer can't check out if a customer can't buy your product you're not making as much money So unfortunately the
bottom line for the business is you know maybe not altruistic Um but that's where
it started And once it started and we could get into that I could start talking to people about we need to do
this because we care Because accessibility matters to all of us We
should all have an equal experience using the web and mobile it's become our
world Everything we do is online And so if we're if we're blocking people from
being able to do the things they need to be able to do the things they want to be able to do you know that's just not
right And so uh you know to care about our fellow human we want to make these
experiences equal and accessible So those are kind of the big reasons why legal to make money and because we care
about our fellow humans What does good
accessibility come down to I think it's it's really understanding
your users your audience and how they're approaching your product So you know
there's a whole range of of limitations I'm not even going to just call them
disabilities cuz sometimes it's limitations sometimes it's a it's a temporary limitation that any of us
could run into at any point in time could be environmental it could be health related like whatever it's it's
that many of us may approach using the web with some sort of limitation whether
it's um manual meaning like we can't use our hands in the same ways Maybe we
can't use a mouse maybe we have dexterity issues maybe it's visual we
either blind or color blind or just have impairment in your vision Maybe it's
auditory you can't hear if if there's something that's um playing Uh so
there's a lot of different ways that people might be limited And so we need to understand based on those limitations
how are they using the web how are they using computers how are they using mobile devices and then actually
experiencing that So I think really we have to try to put ourselves in their
shoes as best we can and test out our applications using those same approaches
that they might be using Maybe it's keyboard only Maybe you can uh up the
contrast Um there's lots of color contrast tools that maybe people who are
color blind might use I've found issues where suddenly buttons on the page
disappeared when the contrast was turned up on the site and so people wouldn't even know that those were there Um
screen readers every device has options of screen readers and so actually using
your site with a screen reader or andor keyboard only is quite a different
experience Uh so really approaching your site with all of those and kind of
seeing like what is that user experience like and how do we need to modify it Are there things that we need
to have the screen reader announce to people Are there things that as the state of the page changes we need to let
them know like this thing is visible now or there's an error and here it is What
what is it and where is it Um so we need to just kind of like approach the user
experience differently And that's why it really helps if you can get you know designers involved in this So it's it's
not landing at the development uh stage It's sort of like what is the user
experience for someone using a screen reader What is it for someone using a keyboard etc Um so then we can develop
matching those experiences There are guidelines Are they useful
It can be overwhelming You know if you go to the various guidelines that are
out there or if you look at the uh uh legal
um well and they vary by country So you know what the laws are in the US for for
accessibility are going to be different from the EU and and and uh so forth So approaching it from that
direction can be really overwhelming like what are all the guidelines How do I go through a checklist and and make
sure my site is doing all of these things Um there are a lot of tools that help us uh that kind of audit for the
lowhanging fruit the things that are just easier to catch um not just
statically but but even at runtime we've got tools that you can run in the browser that as the state of the site
changes it can detect those things but again those are the really easier things
to catch so you can at least start there you know I've always recommended taking
a test-driven approach instead of starting with the guidelines and trying to make sure you're matching them start
with a test-driven approach add the tools that are going to make your job a little easier catch the lowhanging root
and and have it tell you like this is inaccessible And usually they're really
good at telling you why You can get to more documentation that tells you why is this important Why is this a problem
Here's some recommendations on how to fix it And so you can kind of build up
your knowledge set bit by bit of like okay these are the things we typically need to look for and these are the ways
we typically fix them And then you know you can create shared component libraries and things like that So you
really only need to fix it once and it's going to kind of roll out to multiple places So there are ways to kind of help
you be more efficient and kind of get your arms around like all these things to learn and and make sure you're doing
Um but after that you really have to like I said you have to test the app you
have to find the rough edges of like oh this experience is terrible or maybe
technically this is accessible but it's really hard to do what I need to do Um
and then you know adjust that because we care about the user experience or we should but you can go so far as auditors
There are many auditors out there that will test your site and will really go through the checklist and make sure
you're fully compliant There are certifications out there you can get Um but what's tough is it's a moving target
You know every time you add a new feature every time you make a change you might inadvertently have just broken
something about the accessibility of your site So it kind of needs to be baked into the QA process as well to
make sure you're constantly testing and auditing for these things
And as our styles of interaction change so I'm I'm thinking
the for many people today the AI chatbot that's becoming well becoming the core
UI How do we adapt to as developers How
do we adapt to this um the new demands
Yeah again we just have to be constantly testing constantly learning and and
looking into those things That's a great point is that this has become sort of a
new UI uh paradigm that we're running into a
lot And it may be that many of these chatbots I mean it's it's it's one thing just to figure out just to learn how do
I even add this AI chatbot Um but but then digging into making it accessible
So we can't just tack on these things and not continue to do our due diligence
to make sure the experience is still accessible Because if this is going to
become the main way you interface with these products um you know you've just
taken a site that might have been accessible for a lot of people and now added this huge barrier It kind of goes
along with these overlays I'm I'm sure you've seen various websites that have
you know this little icon somewhere the bottom of the page and um with some sort
of accessibility icon on it And uh these overlay products
really sell themselves as like we're going to do all this for you All you have to do is add this this
little thing to your code and we're going to magically make it accessible you don't have to be an expert on
accessibility You just throw this in And that's really false You know there are some ways that
these overlays actually make things less accessible Many of them add in their own
screen reader but it's not as capable as the the screen readers that are either built into the OS or that are natively
available So they really don't fix or make anything better they
actually hamper the accessibility So there's no shortcuts like just like
everything else in software development like we have to learn our craft We have to learn languages and frameworks and
tools and and this should just really be one of the things that everybody well not everybody front-end developers uh
that just kind of becomes part of your tool set becomes part of your skill set
Switching topics slightly you made the point
of your very wide experience has brought you to a
state where you are comfortable now building products for engineers in that
that platform enablement Devx type space What's different when you are
building products for engineers Yeah I mean you know first of all what
drew me there was you know empathy I firsthand understand that experience
when you have a workflow that's painful when you have friction in your
day-to-day work you know your feedback loops are slow or there's just something
awkward or annoying or painful or whatever that you're constantly being hampered and impeded and and just doing
the work that you need to do I know how frustrating that is I also know how hard
it is to be on a product development team where you're constantly under
schedule pressure Uh we've got this feature we've got to get out We've got this looming deadline We don't have time
to go make this thing better or make this easier for us So we're just going to kind of put up with the pain put up
with these things that slow us down We're used to it whatever maybe after
the next feature launches we can come back to it make it better and that that you know maybe in the future never
happens and so I've experienced that over the years and and I was always drawn to taking on those tasks of trying
to make those things better for my team so that my team members can stay heads
down focused on getting those features out and I can try to help enable them to be more efficient Uh so I've always felt
passionate about that So when I had a chance to join a platform team you know that was sort of my argument of I know I
don't have a lot of experience in the ops space or the DevOps space I've got some but I think I bring a perspective
of what it's like to be a a product development engineer and what it's like to deal with these things that are that
are constantly getting in my way and what it's like to work with a platform
or DevOps team what it's like to be on the other side of the wall And so I'm I
was hoping to bring with that this empathy this understanding of the developer perspective And uh you know
there are all these stereotypes of uh you know when you're on the dev side you
might be thinking uh um I really need help with this thing but if I reach out
to platform or devops they're going to think I'm stupid or they don't have time They're so busy with all the stuff that
they have to do they don't have time to help me with this thing Um or we kind of
speak different languages You know they might be saying something that's that's totally over my head and that might be a
little intimidating So you know I have that I I understand what that's like and
and I have felt hampered in the past from collaborating or asking for help
from the DevOps team or the platform team So jumping to the other side was
really fascinating to see the perspective of the platform team working with developers Developers who are
constantly being pushed and rushed and kind of forced to cut corners and thus create problems that the platform team
has to solve or SRRES have to solve And so then there's this stereotyper of devs
are lazy devs are always cutting corners devs don't care about quality or they
don't do their due diligence before they do a thing Um and they don't want to
collaborate with us You know when we ask them uh to work with us to do something like database upgrades for instance we
need to work with them because they need to test their code to make sure it still works with the thing we've upgraded but
they don't have time for this They don't make time for these kinds of things because it's not on their product
roadmap So I saw both sides of of uh you know how we see each other over the wall
Um but having empathy for like what it's like to actually be in the shoes of
either side was super powerful for me and I was able to explain you know to my
teammates I know we think that maybe the devs are being lazy or or maybe they
they should know more about this thing that we're having to help them with Um
but they don't have time they don't you know they're taking on such a high
cognitive load especially these days like as we've added you know so much in
the cloud as we've added so much tooling we've got so many products we've got so many options now and we've shifted left
so much Um you know the DevOps movement shifted a lot left to developers The you
build it you run it developers have to be responsible for a lot a lot of
infrastructure a lot of architectural decisions uh security even as we just
spoke about web accessibility like we've put a lot on their plates and so in order to continue to
meet their deadlines they are forced to cut corners they they aren't able to learn how to use every tool and and how
to really be knowledgeable about everything in the landscape so to kind
explained that to my platform team members of like we've got to keep in mind the context here of of what they're
dealing with And then on the other end how can we as a
platform team kind of change how uh we are seen or interpreted by the
developers so that when they do need help they'll ask for it So they're comfortable asking for the help they
need when they have to reach into this space of like creating new infrastructure for the feature they need
uh or getting the right amount of observability on some new feature when
they need that help We need to be approachable We need to be available or else they're going to do it on their own
Again going back to the DevOps movement we kind of have this concept of devs should just be able to do it all on
their own uh in order to move quickly But that's asking too much these days Um
so we you know I really wanted to promote this idea of like we can meet
you where you're at The platform team can can stretch over the aisle and meet you where you're at And so if you don't
know how to use these tools if you're not knowledgeable about the various infrastructure options available these
days let's collaborate on it Let's work on the architectural design together um
you know bring us in as a partner so that we can help you do these things to
get that feature um ready for production instead of the developer shouldering it
all and not doing as good a job of it because they're in an area they're they're not experienced in They're doing
their best but if they don't have that deep experience they're going to make
mistakes They're going to miss things and and when they miss things it becomes the platform team or the S sur team's
problem later We're going to have to fix that problem that blows up in production
way down the road or we're going to find that we're totally missing observability about something and maybe we have errors
or we have problems that that we don't even know are happening or we're not scaling appropriately Like there's so
many outcomes based on just that that uh
interaction of devs trying to do more than they really are are uh experienced
or set up for success to do and not feeling comfortable asking for help or
collaborating with the platform team So you know building psychological safety
where they feel comfortable they feel safe they don't feel judged being able
to reach out and say "I really need help with this aspect of this feature I'm working on."
Psychological safety an incredibly important concept
that's become a buzzword What does it really mean to create a
safe environment where people can ask those slightly embarrassing questions or
difficult questions Yeah I found that the more I learn about psychological safety the more I start to
see it everywhere and I start to see that uh sort of chain reaction or kind of
root cause analysis on negative outcomes being the result of a lack of
psychological safety And it can be it can be complex It can be subtle because
we're humans We're humans interacting with other humans and we're all
approaching those interactions with preconceived notions and you know whatever our histories are whatever our
psychological issues are So it's complicated but I've really found and
it's been hard for me that the more that I can model vulnerability myself and especially as I've become more senior
over the years the more that I can show that there are things I don't know or there
are mistakes that I make there's questions I have the more I hope I'm
creating this environment for other people to feel like they they can do the same Um you know as I was earlier on in
my career as I was just starting to become more senior I felt a ton of pressure to
prove myself to prove that I deserved the role And you know that created a lot of
bad behavior I was a perfectionist I was a workaholic If there was something I
didn't know I couldn't admit it and I couldn't ask for help because then people would know that I didn't know
everything and I wasn't you know the best So it was really hard to to take on
all that pressure of like oh gez I don't know this thing but I don't want anybody to know that I don't know So now I'm
going to work extra hours I'm going to work all weekend to learn this thing and
try to present myself as if I knew it all along Um and that's really unhealthy And as sort of a negative side effect I
kind of created this this model or I set this bar to my teammates that they had to be perfect too uh when when I never
made any mistakes I always knew everything I had all the answers then then they felt especially the the more
junior people they thought like "Oh this is the standard." And so I too can't ask
questions I too can't ask for help cuz cuz I guess we don't do that here Um and
so I created a really toxic environment around myself without realizing it And so as I got you know a little more
senior a little more experienced and I and I finally started hearing people talking about this I I think that's another thing that's changed a lot over
the years As more people talk about culture as more people talk about psychology and working together the more
I was hearing things about psychological safety and uh how we can impact others
with our behavior when when we're not cognizant about the model we're setting
for others So it was really hard for me to go from that perfectionist I have to be perfect
I have to prove myself to you know what I have to make mistakes I have to show
people that I don't know everything if I want them to feel comfortable working with me if I want us to be able to
collaborate and and I did see examples of where maybe I didn't make the
environment comfortable for others and I and I knew that they had questions or I
knew that they had things they wanted to say you know that I'd find out later that they didn't say to me or they
didn't ask me And so I realized like oh I don't I'm not making people feel
comfortable approaching me or being open with me with their thoughts or disagreeing with me That's a big thing
If I don't make the environment comfortable for people to feel like they can offer an alternate view of something
you know if I make a statement if I pose a thought if I do that in a way that's
too assertive uh it could cause other people to feel like oh um either well
she must know better than I do or if I if I offer this contrary viewpoint I'm
going to sound stupid you know whatever it may be whatever that fear is that they're having in their mind I'm now not
going to hear that alternate viewpoint I might be wrong I'm wrong all the time Uh
maybe there's just some aspect of this that I'm missing or or something that I don't have personal experience with And
so if if I'm kind of shutting off that opportunity to hear that um you know maybe that was a better idea than what I
had Maybe they they thought of something that I that I didn't and I missed And so
we're we're so much better off when we can make people feel comfortable saying "Oh well what about this?" or "Have you
thought about that?" without fear of I don't know it being taken personally It it being feel it feeling like conflict
So somehow we have to create that environment where it's not personal It's it's just normal We can have discourse
and it's comfortable and it's normal and it's how we do our work But again you
have to sort of plant the seeds You have to lay the foundation and that comes from senior people modeling that
behavior you know really I noticed it uh as I was you know gaining experience
when I would see those people that I looked up to that I thought were really smart talented
um when I saw that like they weren't perfect that there was things that they didn't know and they and they felt
comfortable they weren't ashamed they weren't apologetic they were just like "Hey I've got this question." Or "Oh I
just broke this thing in prod." and uh you know just so you know I'm fixing it But it's not apologetic It's not
scraping It's not "Oh I'm I'm so sorry I broke prod I'm so embarrassed." Like we
don't have to be embarrassed We make mistakes And so when you've got that attitude of like "Yeah I I made this
mistake Just FYI I'm working on it." It it really lowers that barrier for us all
to be open about like "Yep I made this mistake Here's what we're going to do about it." Or "I could use some help I
missed this thing or I'm not really knowledgeable about this area that I'm working in Maybe someone else is maybe
they can help me Um and so the more we can just make that normal part of just
how we work Um the more we can allow space for all those things that if if we
didn't have we're not doing our best work
being vulnerable leading by
example It's hard Yeah it's really hard sometimes
Like I almost equate it to I don't know if you've ever jumped off something high up like into like
jumped off into the water or well yeah I guess you'd usually be jumping into water but if you've ever taken a leap
you know I have a fear of heights so that's really scary for me I'm never going to go skydiving or bungee jumping
But those concepts of I'm going to take a leap and I have to believe that I'm
going to be fine It's just this kind of scary little thing that I have to get over But I have the belief that I'm

still to this day feel that way all the time I'll have a question or a problem or whatever and I'll pause and I'll
think if I ask this maybe I'll sound stupid this could be embarrassing
whatever I still have those thoughts Um but then I just remind myself of like
that's okay You know that this is okay and you know that you showing this
little bit of vulnerability on a regular basis is going to help someone else So
that's what kind of helps me take that leap I want a lot of
